title-group.article-title: Principles of Scarce Medical Resource Allocation in Natural Disaster Relief
title-group.subtitle: A Simulation Approach

contrib-group.aff: Department of Industrial Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Hui Cao, PhD, Tsinghua University, Haidian District, Beijing, 100084, China; e-mail: caohui@tsinghua.edu.cn.

abstract.p: Background. A variety of triage principles have been proposed. The authors sought to evaluate their effects on how many lives can be saved in a hypothetical disaster. Objective. To determine an optimal scarce resource–rationing principle in the emergency response domain, considering the trade-off between lifesaving efficiency and ethical issues. Method. A discrete event simulation model is developed to examine the efficiency of four resource-rationing principles: first come–first served, random, most serious first, and least serious first. Seven combinations of available resources are examined in the simulations to evaluate the performance of the principles under different levels of resource scarcity. Result. The simulation results indicate that the performance of the medical resource allocation principles is related to the level of the resource scarcity. When the level of the scarcity is high, the performances of the four principles differ significantly. The least serious first principle performs best, followed by the random principle; the most serious first principle acts worst. However, when the scarcity is relieved, there are no significant differences among the random, first come–first served, and least serious first principles, yet the most serious first principle still performs worst. Conclusion. Although the least serious first principle exhibits the highest efficiency, it is not ethically flawless. Considering the trade off between the lifesaving efficiency and the ethical issues, random selection is a relatively fair and efficient principle for allocating scarce medical resources in natural disaster responses.

body.p: Earthquakes and secondary disasters alone have killed more than 800,000 people since the start of the 21st century,1 including the recent tsunami of December 2004 in the South Asian region (over 220,000 deaths in 14 countries) and the Sichuan earthquake of May 2008 in China (over 69,000 dead and 374,000 injured2). Over the last 5 or 6 years, there is an increasing trend in earthquake deaths.1 The trend warns that we are still not prepared to face an overwhelming number of casualties, despite technological advances. There is an urgent need to reevaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the existing disaster response systems. Large-scale catastrophic events typically result in a scarcity of essential medical resources.

Usually, clinicians use triage to determine which patients receive treatments in a mass casualty disaster.3 However, there has been much debate addressing problems from the legal, ethical, and emotional considerations that arise when the triage system is implemented.4 For example, who should receive the limited resources? Should those with the highest risk of mortality receive intervention? Who should make the allocation decisions?5

Childress6 suggested that any well-designed random selection procedure would be preferable to social worth systems, but Forsberg7 argued that randomness is less rational than social worth system. According to Iserson and Pesik,3 the considerations of common triage models include treating the most serious first, first come–first served, social value of the patients, and best prognosis of the patients. Kilner8 proposed a random selection policy from among those medically qualified but with exceptions for those facing imminent death, those requiring disproportionately few resources, and those having extreme unique moral duties, whereas other aspects, such as age, social value, and willingness to pay, should not be considered in the allocation of scarce medical resources.

Recently, Persad et al.9 evaluated eight simple principles: lottery—allocate the resources randomly to all the patients; first come–first served; sickest first; youngest first; maximize number of lives saved; maximize life-years saved; instrumental value—allocating resources prioritized to specific individuals to enable or encourage future usefulness; and reciprocity—allocating resources prioritized to those who implement important values. Persad et al.9 pointed out that no single principle is sufficient; thus, individual principles must be combined in implementation. This finding is somewhat consistent with Katz,10 who explored existing guidance on how to allocate scarce medical resources and then declared that there was no such guidance that can solve all ethical problems. Nevertheless, Katz10 believed that a fair and well-articulated system for allocating medical resources should be designed and then turned to the public for a referendum.

Most quantitative models for managing natural disasters11 focus on transportation and location issues; few models have been developed to compare the efficiency of different resource-rationing principles in natural disaster response. Here, efficiency means the proportion of lives that are saved in a natural disaster under the application of a system for allocating scarce resources.8 After ruling out universally unacceptable allocation criteria (e.g., willingness to pay, relationship with the decision maker), the efficiency of proposed allocation systems should be considered in the development of a fair and well-articulated system when it is hard to tell which system is more fair.

This article focuses on evaluating the performance of different principles in emergencies. Given the observed data from a recent powerful earthquake, we describe a simulation study used to examine the performance of different rationing principles in a hypothetical earthquake scenario.

sec.title: Simulation Model
sec.p: We developed a simulation model and used it to evaluate the efficiency of four resource allocation principles:

list-item.p: First come–first served (FCFS): allocate the resources to the earliest arrivals
Random selection (RAN): allocate the resources randomly to all patients
Most serious first (MSF): allocate the resources to the sickest patients
Least serious first (LSF): allocate the resources to the least serious patients

sec.p: The simulation model focuses on the overall patient flow in the hospital emergency department following an earthquake (adapted and simplified from Gao et al.12) (Figure 1). After patients arrive at the hospital, they are directed to the triage process. On the basis of triage results, critical patients are sent to the emergency department, waiting for operations (emergency operation) or other treatments (emergency treatment), while noncritical patients are required to register their information at the registration desks, where they are assigned to specialized departments for necessary operations or other treatments. Treatment in these specialized departments is not addressed in the model.
The model addresses the following emergency department resources:

list-item.p: General doctors, who are involved in the triage process
General nurses, who are in charge of registration and separation
Senior doctors, who are required at emergency and nonemergency operations
Specialized doctors, who take care of nonemergency treatments
Surgical tables, which are required in emergency and nonemergency operations
Surgical groups, consisting of the surgeons, anesthesiologist, nurses, and so on, required to perform a surgery

sec.p: We assumed that a senior doctor, a surgical group, and a surgical table are mandatory for performing a surgery. For other emergency or nonemergency treatment, a senior doctor or a specialized doctor is required. The assignment of doctors is based on their preferred tasks and the availability of the resources. In emergency treatment a senior doctor is preferred, while a specialized doctor is preferred in nonemergency treatment. However, the resources are transferable between the processes; that is, when the nonemergency treatment queue is empty, the specialized doctors can be redirected to emergency treatment upon request and vice versa.

sec.title: Patients’ arriving rate
sec.p: It has been reported that the first wave of the hospital arrivals are mainly patients with minor injuries.18,19 The number of the arrivals increased rapidly after a couple of hours19 or 12 hours18 or 2 days.20 In the meantime, the conditions of the patients arriving later were typically more serious.19
In this article, the arrival data observed by Zhao et al.13 at the People’s Hospital of Deyang City in Sichuan after the earthquake are employed in our simulation models.

Provided that the hospital was open 24 hours a day, with the daily arrival numbers from 12 to 31 May 2008 given by Zhao et al.,13 linear and nonlinear regression was used to capture the hospital arrival behavior over time. sec.title: Initial lifesaving rate
sec.p: In the simulation model, the severity of sickness is measured by the value of lifesaving rate (LSR). LSR takes values from 0 to 1. A person’s LSR is identified as 1 when he or she is in a healthy state and 0 when dead; otherwise, LSR is a decimal value between 0 and 1. The initial LSR value is that when a patient arrivals at the hospital. Jiang et al.14 presented a triage method used in the West China Hospital of Sichuan University during its response to the Sichuan earthquake. Table 3 summarizes the numbers of patients fitted to each triage category, according to data reported by Jiang et al.14 In this article, each triage category is assigned with a range of LSR values (Table 3); for example, for patients who require immediate treatment, their LSR values range between 0.1 and 0.2. sec.title: Treatment times
sec.p: Since critical patients usually require disproportionately more resources than noncritical patients, two triangular distributions are used in generation of treatment time for critical and noncritical patients based on the values reported by Hupert et al.17

sec.title: Outcome and Sensitivity Analysis
sec.p: To evaluate the performance of different allocation principles under different levels of resource scarcity, seven combinations of available resources are employed in the simulations. Table 4 lists the resource portfolios involved in the simulation. In the simulation, when the LSR value of a patient is less than 0.05, the patient is regarded as dead.

The simulation terminates at 10 days (14,400 minutes). Since the patient interarrival times are calculated by the regression equation described above, the numbers of arrivals in all replications are equal to 1,734, whereas the number of patients processed varies from 1,731 to 1,734 when the replications terminate. Thus, the efficiency of the evaluated allocation principles can be measured by the death toll itself.

To compare the death tolls generated by the simulation, two tests have been performed for each pair of allocation principles using SPSS software. One test assumes that the variances of the two groups are equal, which is tested by the Levine statistic tests. The assumption that the means of the two groups are equal is then tested by a two-tailed t test.

sec.title: Modeling Software and Hardware
sec.p: The simulation model is implemented using the Arena simulation software package (version 12.00.00–CRP 9, developed by Rockwell Automation Technologies). The simulation software is installed on a laptop running Microsoft Windows 7 (64-bit Enterprise version), and the laptop is equipped with an Intel Core i3-330M CPU (2.13GHz) and 4GB of memory.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The average death tolls for each principle are illustrated in Figure 2. Table 5 displays the average waiting time for the patients before they get treatment, and Table 6 shows the average percentage decrease of LSR from initial LSR to time of treatment. The data show that for each principle, the average waiting time and the average decrease of LSR both decrease when the resource scarcity decreases. The influences of the medical resource allocation principles are related to the level of the resource scarcity. For resource combinations 1 to 4, the differences among the four principles are all significant (see Table 7 for the average values and standard deviations of the death tolls, the t test results, and the P values). For resource combination 7, there is no significant difference among the performances of the RAN, FCFS, and LSF principles. The MSF principle performs worst in all seven combinations.

sec.p: When resources are scarcer, LSF and RAN had lower deterioration rates and death rates but higher average waiting times than FCFS and MSF (e.g., resource combinations 1 and 2 in Tables 5 and 6). The reason is that more patients remaining alive leads to longer total waiting time when the given medical resources are limited.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Treating the most serious first is an instinctive option favored by many authors (e.g., Iserson and Pesik,3 Kilner8). This principle appeals to “rule of rescue,” especially when resources are temporarily scarce.9 We created a discrete event simulation model to evaluate the performance of four principles under different levels of resource scarcity. The results show that the MSF principle displays a much poorer outcome than the other three principles, especially when resources are extremely scarce. This occurs because, over time, less serious patients deteriorate and turn into serious patients while waiting for resources. However, implementation of the LSF principle instead of the MSF principle may be problematic from an ethical perspective. Treating a patient in a sustainable condition but leaving a critical patient to die is not easily acceptable, even though it promises higher efficiency.

Usually, the FCFS principle is an instinctive method of resource allocation for a nonemergency situation, and it is supported by some authors (e.g., Childress6). However, it has been criticized for favoring wealthy, powerful, and well-connected groups because they are able to arrive earlier owing to their transportation and information resources.9,10 In this study the FCFS principle has only better performance than the MSF principle. Random rationing of limited medical resources, which has been suggested by many authors on the basis of ethical considerations, was superior to all principles except the least serious first. Thus, owing to the ethical flaw of the LSF principle, the RAN principle is a relatively fair and acceptably efficient principle for allocating scarce medical resources in natural disaster response.

sec.title: Limitation and Future Work
sec.p: It should be noted that the above findings are dependent on data collected from a single event—a major earthquake in southwest China. The arrival rate and triage data may be dramatically different in other places where the geography, population density, community infrastructure, and so on, are different. Thus, the result of this article is limited to the specific earthquake and may not be applicable to all earthquakes worldwide.

The findings of this research indicate that it is important to fully explore the behavior of different allocation principles under different situations. Besides the evaluation of different patient arrival patterns, some possible extensions include the following: (1) This article used the patients’ arrival data, the triage data, and so on, observed from a major earthquake. Other data, such as the type of injury, treatment time, and waiting time for each patient, should be included to enhance the validation of the simulation model. (2) The influence of different types of injures has not yet been considered. With the availability of more data and information, it would be possible to distinguish the detailed treatment flow for each injury type. (3) In addition to human resources and operating rooms, other resources, such as medical equipment, devices, and drugs, are worth including in the simulation. (4) It might also be possible to achieve more superior performance by assigning principles and allocating resources based on the degree of sickness. For example, the most resources might be allocated to the sickest patients who would be treated under a RAN, while the least sick patients might be allocated the fewest resources and treated under a first come–first-served principle.
